I quit weed over 2 years ago, since then I've had constant feelings of anxiety, insomnia, sleeping issues, I sleep 10+ hours daily, sudden weight gain.

Went to a doctor but after all tests I got them to do, turns out I'm "fine" medically. Went to therapy, had to quit because too sleep deprived to pay attention. Tried antidepressants but they make things worse and side effects are too severe, tried all available types too.

Thought maybe its some sort of sleep disorder? asked doctor to refer me to a sleep clinic, they rejected me saying I need to go to therapy instead. Tried getting a job, thought maybe not working makes me depressed? quit after a month because physically my body wasn't able to cope with the stress and being sleep deprived despite getting 8 hours of sleep, but not because I was tired, but because I was worn out from stress, anxiety and other issues that having a job didn't fix.

Asked to see a psychiatrist to assess me. Waited nearly a year for appointment, went in for 10 minutes, was told to try and find direction in my life, get a job and try therapy in order to do that, completely dismissed the fact I quit my job and therapy BECAUSE of the issues I've been having that I came here to address. Now got a letter saying that due to so many appointments for therapy, they won't be able to take me in for weeks to come and that I have to wait for available slots. Check up with psychiatrist is at the end of April...

How is it that when I tried to fix my problems on my own, I felt less helpless and felt better than I do now? I actually feel like I can't be helped and I've run out of options at this point. What more can I do? I spent nearly 3 years at this and its only getting worse... I just want my life to be over already, I tried, but its not working, I really did want to get better but now I just want peace and be done with it.

>>28130403
You might be experiencing some form of adrenal fatigue:
https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2017/07/170731090828.htm

Since adrenal fatigue is mostly not recognized as a clinical condition you may have to self-diagnose. Here are a couple ways you can do that:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SvBi5A6iS9I

You may want to get a HOMA-IR test done to see if you have subclinical insulin resistance which could be contributing to your problem. If it is then intermittent fasting with a no refined sugar, low carb diet may provide some benefit. Thiamine supplementation, along with the other B-Complex vitamins, may help as well as these vitamins are necessary for proper adrenal health. Two teaspoons of non-fortified organic nutritional yeast mixed with almond butter may be a good habit to start your mornings as it contains most of the B vitamins your adrenals require for proper function.
A month of NAC supplementation, at 1200mg/day 600 2x/day, could be helpful if your body has been able to replete glutathione levels after so many years of marijuana use, especially int he lungs:
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10340948/
https://www.amazon.com/Pure-Encapsulations-NAC-Glycine-Powder/dp/B08WJDLHMJ

That handles the physiological part of it. Unfortunately the psychological part is far more complicated. And really there's not much I can recommend for the psychological part as much of it is dependent on your environment. With chronic stress being capable of inducing your symptoms on its own, even proper nutrition may be ineffective. That doesn't mean you shouldn't try to get the physiological side in order. Physiological health should, at the least, help to make your stress symptoms more manageable. I think it's worth trying for at least a month. When both your physiological and psychological conditions become dysregulated it's nearly impossible to achieve and maintain state which allows you to transact with society on a regular basis.

Self improvement isn't about what it can get you externally. It's about the internal gains you make, the widening of perception and the greater understanding of self and enlightenment to the world around you.

It's the rejection of anger, fear, and negative emotions that hold you back from what you really desire, and an acceptance and love of ones self. To approach the world with kindness, compassion and understanding as appropriate.

Those things can lead to the external things you want, however undertaking such self reflection inevitably changes what you want. Perhaps more importantly however if seeing to get something external remains the motivation one can never genuinely self improve not matter how long they try. It must be an earnest desire in the individual to be a better person for themselves.

You simply are doing it wrong.

>>28130361
Definitely hit Osaka, Kyoto and Toyko if you can. I'll list some of the attractions but honestly there is heaps to do.

In Osaka see the Osaka Castle, Nara deer park and Shinsekai district.

In Kyoto see Nijo Castle, Thousands Torii Gate and Kiyomizu-dera with the surrounding old shopping streets.

In Tokyo, go up the Skytree and Tokyo Tower, and visit akihabara and shinbyua.

In terms of accommodation you can honestly just wing it at grab a cheap place from Expedia or whatever, they tend to be good. Tokyo was harder to find a location.

Make sure to get the JRAIL pass to save money too.

Hopefully that helped anon, let me know if you have any other questions.

posts.com:
How do I deal with this situation?

A bit of backstory:

In 2021,

....a Former High School classmate of mine (from the mid-2000s) died.

In high school we were in some classes together, but I wasn't close with them. We did share some mutual friends, but we never hung out together.

After graduation, we all parted ways. Some of us even moved far away. Our graduating class tried to stay connected on social media. But you know how that goes. Social Media isn't a replacement for real life. We all moved on.

In 2021, the news broke on social media that my classmate died suddenly. I reached out to a mutual friend for more info. I sent my deceased classmate's family a sympathy card.

I guess they had a private funeral. I didn't hear of anything else. I was not close to their family (I never met them). All I could do was send a sympathy card and move on.

This was 2 years ago.

-------------------------

In 2023...

2 years later, suddenly out of nowhere I received a card from my deceased classmate's mother.

The mother apologized and said she's been very depressed and sad these passed 2 years. But that out of ALL sympathy cards she received, my card meant the most to her. More than any other card from other classmates, friends, or family. It really meant so much to her. (huh?)

Then the mother then asked me if she could speak with me, and even meet in-person.

--------------------

1. I have no idea why my card was the most treasured. I'm very confused. My sympathy card was nothing special. I was just polite, briefly explained who I was, and expressed my condolences for their family's loss. That's it.

How should I handle this? I'm very surprised at this message. I know there were many other people who were much closer to my former classmate than me. I feel awkward.

I'm trying to keep an open mind, but what is going on? Why is the mother contacting me 2 years later, and asking to speak to me, and meet me in person? Why me? She doesn't know me.

Thoughts?

Adulthood is easy. You're still just a big kid, but now you have money and agency.

Now that you're an adult, the only thing thing that will change is that people will now expect you to provide for yourself.

'Providing for yourself' means:
>Earning a source of income (don't be a leech)
>Providing for your own necessities (food/shelter/clothing/doctor's appointments/transport/etc...)
>Meeting your own goals, without someone having to nag you and egg you on 24/7 (if you want to be a doctor, you're not meeting that goal by being a bum and never going to university, are ya?)
>Preparing for the future (look after your health, save up some money for emergencies, if you want kids and a wife in the future, get a good job to support them and don't do dumb shit like shoplifting or heroin).

You're allowed to fuck around and act like a kid 90% of the time. But you do need to follow those basic rules. It's ez.

>>28112537
HPV is incurable, and can sometimes lead to cancer; if you get a strain which causes warts, the individual warts can be treated, but this is painful, and they will keep popping up for several years at least.

HIV is incurable; it is usually treatable, but the drugs are very expensive and can have nasty side effects; you need to take them for life. Occasionally the drugs stop working and people die.

Herpes is incurable, and infects you for life - outbreaks become less frequent with time, but they never stop; herpes simplex 2 is excruciatingly painful; there are drugs that will help treat an outbreak, but you can't take them constantly.

Chlamydia, syphilis and gonorrhoea are usually treatable with antibiotics, but antibiotic-resistant strains of gonorrhoea and syphilis are becoming steadily more common. Note that syphilis can cause insanity or death if it isn't treated, which happens more often than you'd think, because the initial symptoms disappear after a month or two, then it comes back with a vengeance years later, having quietly damaged your central nervous system in the mean time.

Hepatitis is untreatable - you will probably eventually recover from it after several years, but you'll be very sick indeed while you're waiting; it does sometimes kill.

There are other types of bacterial infection that you can pick up from sex; these are generally treatable with antibiotics.

>>28126763
Right OP, you're obviously stuck in this loop, so its probably a good idea that you take a long, hard look at some essential facts about interpersonal relations.

First of all, other people don't think about you at all. When people quietly suffer hoping that the people that care about them will pick up on it and offer help, they are in fact exacerbating the problem. Nobody is going to do this because they don't want extra problems, extra emotions, or more commitment than they already have to themselves. We only tolerate extra commitment when it comes to finding someone to fuck and have kids, and even then, people don't deal with it very well - just look at all the shitty siblings and parents out there.

The truth of it is, while your brother is an asshole, and it isn't your fault these things happened to you in and of itself, nobody is ever going to want to talk about it, and you can expect similar responses from most people when confronted with your trauma. They'll either laugh it off, avoid the issue, or blame you to get the impetus for response to go away.

Your friends won't want to talk about it either - they're too busy dealing with their own traumas, emotions and adult obligations and don't have time for anyone else's.

The only person who is going to want to hear about this sort of thing is a Therapist, because they're specifically paid huge sums of money to listen to other people talk about their problems.

>Is this what I'm destined for? A vow of silence because I have nobody to talk to?

Now you know why most people walk around being constantly unhappy, angry at traumas that only they understand, slowly going crazy or gaining substance abuses as they get older. The trick is learning to live with your issues until you get old and die, there is no permanent resolution for your feelings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28128710
People care in a theoretical sense insofar as we live in a society and the health of other people is, in an abstract way, the health of our community and thus ourselves. We care because caring (to a degree) helps us.

It stops being a thing that helps you the very moment you're expected to do anything about it, even listen - taking on extra burden is not a thing anyone wants to do. People are perfectly fine espousing good behavior and morals so long as they're not actually expected to put forth any effort.

>None of this shit is true
Not only is it true, its always been this way. Societies going all the way back to the BC-era Roman Republic have continually decried how disinterested and self-serving citizens become when it comes time to actually do something about all of the societal issues they constantly complain about. Tacitus and Cicero, as well as Pliny the Younger are all good sources if you want to put it in historical perspective.

>I've been seeing way too many people say shit similar to this in the last few years
Then how come you think it isn't true when you're patently seeing people admit to this in front of your own eyes? The only thing that's really changed is that nobody bothers with the veneer of good behavior anymore - we're allowing our self-interested natures and nihilism to show by wearing it on our sleeves, that doesn't mean things haven't always been this way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28128710
>It takes a real fucking shit friend, and a shit human being in general to not care about others' problems

I do care about others' problems, I simply expect them to deal with those problems themselves or come actively seeking help when they need it, with the full understanding that I am not obligated to help but must volunteer my help and effort. That is the way life works in most civilized countries.

I'm an adult, you're an adult, I already have a full time job just taking care of myself. I expect all other adults to do the full time job of taking care of themselves as well. If you need help, ask for it. I'm not a mind-reader and I don't spend enough time thinking about you, or any one individual other person, enough to pick up on the fact that you need help if you're not going to say so.

Once we've identified that you need help, the response will be weighted by how much I care, which in turn is weighted by how much of a positive impact you have on my life. Then a cost-reward analysis will be performed in which I decide whether or not its 'worth it' to me to help you.

At no point during this exchange did I or anyone else, including your friends, volunteer to be your personal therapist. You're supposed to use introspection to manage your emotions and plenty of people out there either have to do drugs, take antidepressants, or quietly be a wreck in private in order to get by. You would not be the first and you won't be the last.

The important question is whether or not you're willing and able to do these things and thus manage yourself as an adult, but that IS what's expected. You can be as much of an abusive alcoholic as you like as long as you do it in private.

If this is actually you OP, then I really don't think you have as much to worry about than you think you do.

Women are attracted to mannerisms as much as physical appearance. They are attracted to ways of thinking, intellect, humour, etc. etc. It's more nuanced than you'd think. If this girl is as intellectually switched on as you say then I'm sure she's privy to nuance in human beings.

Plus you said you've already made moves on her. You held her hand, and you've kissed her on the head. Those are romantic gestures, and if she hasn't been weirded out by them or questioned you on them, I'm sure she knows the nature of your relationship is leaning towards a romantic one.

Honestly just get more comfortable doing these small gestures with her. Don't rush in to kiss her just yet, just gauge her engagement with your gestures. Eventually you should just tell her how much you like her. Assure her how much you enjoy her company, the discussions you share, etc. and see if she feels the same. She honestly just sounds shy. Maybe you could ask her about her history with dating, bring it up casually as a point of interest, see if she gets uncomfortable or warms up to it. Be vulnerable, honest, guide her along a sort of path to 'get the point' that you're interested in pursuing something romantic with her.
This is all the advice I can offer, as you say not to be 'normie', but just ask if you can kiss her. Because there really is no quicker way to find out if a girl likes you like that or not.

I felt the same way at 18 op and that was in 1997, I didn't have the internet until like a year later though and it really wasn't more than just a novelty until about 2010 for me outside of illegal downloads and porn but I grew up in a small town. Thought I'd never get anywhere or do anything.
Things are definitely fucky now and it was all definitely easier back then.
Get out of your comfort zone, you're going to fuck up and make mistakes but you'll also start to actually figure yourself out. Everything seemed so drastically important at that age and none of it was.
I'm by no means successful but I'm comfortable and content with my life lived now. Mix shit up, if you're not in school maybe look into a tech school or a trade school. I went to college and still ended up homeless for a while and ended up in a trade in the end because it pays way better than the shit I went to college for.
Think of your early 20s and late teens as immersion therapy for the person you'll become. Do stupid shit, take some risks, you have decades left and very few things you do now will impact you for the rest of your life.
Fuck man, go hit the road with your buddy and take a road trip. When I was 18 I would have never thought I'd sleep on a hotel room floor with 20 other people in new Orleans at Mardi gras just a few years later. I wouldn't do it today but it doesn't mean it isn't a fond memories.
It's fucking hard getting out of your comfort zone but if you don't you're gonna blink and 20 years will be gone and you'll wonder what the hell happened.
What are you interested in? What do you wish you could do?

Be the friend your brother doesn't have. Be the friend you'd want if you were you're him. That's why he's doing them in the first place. Addiction is in his life for a reason. Not all of us need to learn the lesson of addiction but some of us do, those of us that are too open, too friendly, too careless, too cool, too nice, too receptive to the world around us are the ones that become easily addicted. I used to be addicted to opiates and I hated my sister. She would literally see me out walking and wouldn't even give me a ride, would drive right past me. She'd throw food away she bought just so I couldn't eat it, she had me thrown in jail once, we have no relationship whatsoever. I hate my sister deep down. I see her and talk to her every now and then but it's awkward because she's a lot cooler now that I'm clean but I still hate her for how she treated me during my addiction. Don't be the brother that he ends up hating because you sat back an judged him like a snob. You're no better than him whatsoever, his lessons are just different than yours. Help him, go out of your way to show him you're there for him. Ask em if he wants to go out our something. Most of all, if you really don't agree with what he's doing then move out so you don't have to see it and don't end up losing a relationship with your brother. Don't sit there and make yourself mad because your obsessed with your brothers drug problem and cause you guys to fall out. Just say bro I love you but I can't be around and watch you do this. >>28129936
T14 schools are generally out of your league at this point unless you are a legacy admit. Law school is tough financially mentally it's pretty easy. You have to do the cost benefit analysis to figure out if going to a lower to your school is worthwhile in your market and or future practice area. The ABA post employment statistics from all the schools and the lsac has an admissions predictor that is good give it a look.

Lastly many undergrad students overestimate what their lsat score will be. It is very unlikely you'll get a 170, puts you in the top few percent of the entire country.

>Am I in the wrong for feeling like it's alright to have a safety net?
You're in the right inasmuch as you aren't actually committed to each other yet, so naturally you shouldn't act as if your relationship is guaranteed to last.
If you were married, then you *would* have committed, and presumably you would only have done that if you were certain it was a good idea. In that case, while a very basic safety net is fine (because tragedies and betrayals unfortunately can still happen), any healthy relationship will barely pay any attention to something that neither partner has any conceivable reason to make use of. So your bf would only have a point if you were still acting distant and fiercely independent even within a marriage.

Although, if you're already living together and/or having sex without being married, you're still missing the point of a safety net and are silly to fixate on being able to break things off when you've already given so much of yourself. He'd also be silly to make a big deal out of commitment if he's fine acting like that without it.

Think of things as if you were in his position, but with your current worries/fears. You said that you would prefer to be the provider because it means YOU will never get hurt. I'm sure he feels somewhat similar. He wants some assurance that HE will not get hurt. He wants some assurance that you will not abandon him the moment things get hairy. You're worried that the person you know will abandon you (or change for the worse, which is another type of 'abandonment'), and you will get hurt.

Really, it sounds like you both want the same thing. You both want security. The issue is that you can't bring yourself to let down your guard, and that's scaring him.

It's good to have a backup plan in case things go wrong in the relationship. But you MUST take some risks and prove to him that you trust him.

Maybe you can meet him halfway here?
Let him know the source of your fears, and let him know what he can do to help you feel more secure.
In return, ask what you can do to make him feel more secure. He will likely ask you to undertake some shared responsibility with him (moving in together/buying a house together/saving for an important shared utility, like a car/moving somewhere with him/etc...)

Tbh he sounds like a great bf, from the way you've described him. I don't know you guys, but it sounds like he's a good person to take that leap with. People who are secretly assholes DO NOT EVER perform this kind of communication with their partners. He's brought up something that makes him feel insecure. FASFA is federal and covers all university/colleges, it may not cover all of your classes and fees if you go somewhere expensive though, but there’s also payment plans n shiiiet
>loans
Idk what to tell you mate, been poor my whole life and have an assload of debt, they can’t tap you if you end up too poor to pay. For most of the gap between my universities, I paid 0 monthly because I didn’t have any substantial income. I dont have anything to lose tho.

Worse thing that could happen to me is succeeding and having a monthly bill to meet while I have a job.
>excuses
Good, best advice now is google Nd research places you’re interested in and deadlines for scholarships, admissions, fafsa etc.
>relatable shit
Yeah man don’t worry. It feels good when you know there’s options and people have gone through what you have. Means there’s a resource you can tap for knowledge. It’s not uncommon, especially these days.

Just take it as easy as you can and don’t beat yourself up. Life isn’t a race, we’re all just growing and learning at our own pace. It takes some time to figure out what to do, especially in these trying times.

Best of luck, anon! Liked the pic you have for OP btw. Midoriya is very relatable.

>>28130579
Have you even looked up symptoms of nicotine withdrawal, you absolute fapwaffle?


https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4542051/pdf/nihms-671027.pdf


The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5) reports 7 primary
symptoms associated with nicotine withdrawal: irritability/anger/frustration, anxiety,
depressed mood, difficulty concentrating, increased appetite, insomnia, and restlessness
(American Psychiatric Association 2013). The syndrome might also include constipation,
dizziness, nightmares, nausea, and sore throat. For practical purposes, nicotine withdrawal
symptoms are classified as affective, somatic, and cognitive. Affective symptoms include
anxiety, anhedonia, depression, dysphoria, hyperalgesia, and irritability. Somatic
manifestations include tremors, bradycardia, gastrointestinal discomfort, and increased
appetite. Cognitive symptoms manifest as difficulty concentrating and impaired memory
(Heishman et al. 2010). This constellation of symptoms reflects the brain-wide influence of
cholinergic transmission. Studies characterizing the participation of specific nAChRs in
signaling during particular manifestations of withdrawal are helping to reveal their
underlying mechanisms (Paolini and De Biasi 2011).


Irritability, frustration, and anger are literally the first three listed.

I quit for the third time in my life about two and a half months ago. I do it cold turkey when I quit. Sudden drastic life changes have typically lead to me smoking.

Short temper, irritability are all symptoms of nicotine withdrawal. Give it two to six months and you'll feel fine. Cravings will occur less frequently. Life will begin to feel normal again after about half a year.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28132988
Take it from a former opera singer, OP. Learn the basics of singing and you'll learn how to talk and sound better. I'm not telling you to actually sing scales or vocal exercises (although they can't hurt!). Watch some singing tutorials and apply those same lessons regarding the mechanisms of your mouth, diaphragm, vocal chords, etc. to regular talking. I'll spoon feed you on some basic pointers and exercises. Learn to open your soft pallet on the roof of your mouth, drop your larynx, breathe from your stomach instead of your chest, and speaking from the stomach instead of your chest. Some ways to learn how to do these things are: learning how to keep the yawning position while talking, singing while shitting, tightening your abs while exhaling and talking. You'll feel silly at first, but so long as you've learned how to articulate your words properly whilst doing the exercises, you'll notice your voice is stronger, louder, and clearer. It will be natural. Think of a good end goal as well. What kind of general tone are you going for? How does this target voice mesh with the tools you've been given? Personally, when I am speaking with good technique I sound a little bit like Han Solo in the original Star Wars film mixed with my own local accents/inflections. When I'm not speaking with good technique (usually for comedic effect by lowering my soft pallet and making the overall space in my mouth and neck smaller), I sound like my teenage self. Both voices are mine, but there's a notable difference, and only one truly reflects the man I've become. You're not wrong for not wanting to be a singer, but don't write off the principles of singing; learning these strategies can help you reach your goals and learn more about yourself in the process.

Okay, so you want cushy, climate-controlled office jobs with no backbreaking labor that are also actually careers instead of working in a call center or something. The jobs that literally the entire human race would give their eyeteeth and their first born child for, and you're competing with the downsizing of the economy, people who have more seniority than you, and the immigrant labor market who will accept less than the minimum you need just to pay your bills. You don't have any certifications and you're in the running with basically every human being alive.

You deal with this by getting a job doing things people don't want to do for a living, just like everyone else. Something boring, hard on your body, dead-end job, stinks at work, etc. etc.

Always remember that the whole reason people get paid to do a job is because other people don't want to do it so badly that they're willing to pay you to do the work. Banking on having skills that other people (Don't, will never) have is folly - we're a big global market now and also staring down the barrel of AI and Machine Labor.
